chapter.title: Book Overview
chapter.para: In the following paragraphs I will present a brief explanation of the contents of each chapter and section. Section titles are emphasised while Chapter titles are strongly emphasised.
chapter.formalpara: I. Structure of a graphical application Looking at the code of some of the many open source applications avialable, we can find common components in their structure. This chapter introduces the concept of a Event loop and how does it deal with the interaction between the functionality and the interface.
chapter.para: I.I. Decomposing the frontend. There are different approaches to the creation of Graphical User Interfaces, some provide more flexibilty while others development speed. In any case, the end product will make available the same mechanisms to the rest of the application.
chapter.formalpara: II. Introduction to Edje Edje is a compromise between flexibilty and development time. Comparing it to a plain canvas or a fully featured toolkit can show us how it fits in a comfortable middle ground with advantages for designers and developers alike.
chapter.para: II.I. The foundations. Edje allows low level control of the interface without forcing the developer through a low level API. The interface objects are implemented as Evas objects, but through a compeletely new language friendly to designers and independent from the application code.

II.II.Convenient functions. To load an Edje interface the application needs to setup an Evas canvas first. This would look as a burden for the developer, dealing with issues specific to the underlying system. Thankfully Evas is supported by an additional library that resolve most of these issues, Ecore.
chapter.formalpara: III. The foundations in practice This is a practical example of the simplest approach to setting up an Evas canvas for display.
chapter.para: III.I Working with the canvas Another example dealing with the inclusion of an Edje object.
III.II Interacting with the objects A practical guide through both Edje and plain Ecore's event system.
chapter.formalpara: IV. Introduction to widgets A simple description of what a widget is and what it is useful for along with the limitations presented by common toolkits.
chapter.para: IV.I. The common widget design A generic vision of the way the different toolkits design the structure of widgets with the corresponding diagram.
IV.II. Widget design with Edje An explanation about where does Edje fits in the structure mentioned before, and the shortcuts it provides.
chapter.formalpara: V. Implementing a widget with Edje A brief resume of the previous chapter and the introduction of names specific to Evas, Ecore_Evas and Edje.
chapter.para: V.I. The backend (temporary section name) it will include the C implementation of widgets in a way similar to EWL.
V.II. The frontend (Another temporary section name) it will include the EDC Implementation of the widget in a way it fits the method used by the EWL developers.
V.III. The Inclusion (Another temporary section name) it will include the method to insert the custom widget in the application.
V.IV. Saving time with EWL widgets Introduction to EWL widgets, a brief list of what is available and the method to include the widgets in the application.
V.V. Interaction The final example showing how to interact with the combination of EWL, custom and non-widget elements in our application.

section.title: Useful resources
section.para:
Before we begin I would list a collection of books and articles that I found critical while understanding about the Enlightenment Foundation Libraries.
The Edje API Reference by Carsten Haitzler.
Building Interfaces with Edje: The Edje Developers Guide by Ben Rockwood.
The EFL Cookbook by several authors.
Introduction to the Enlightenment foundation libraries by Kostis Kapelonis.
Evas Tutorials by rephorm
